in Meditation, Consciousness, Enlightenment, Spirituality
1 hour ago, Bacher said:

The thing is, all your answers come from the perspective of absolute truth.

This is not the case.

Most of my advice pertains to the relative domain. In your case of dealing with these healers, I'm telling you to be careful precisely for relative reasons. They can give you bad/wrong advice and you just trust them and ruin your life.

In dealing with some of these spiritual healer type people I have found many of them to be full of shit and it would be very foolish to entrust important life decisions to them. I'm not saying it's all bad, but you gotta be skeptical of things they say because they say some bullshit that will directly contradict other spiritual healers.

For example, I went to a top rated spiritual healer last year and asked her specifically about my health problems. She told me there is absolutely nothing wrong with my body. At first I believed her. Then I did medical testing and found out otherwise, and conclusively proved to myself that she was full of shit as I started taking medicine and feeling much better.

Now, will she ever admit her mistake? Never. She's too high on her own spiritual bullshit.

So from now on any time someone tells me they are a spiritual healer, I will look at them like they are an idiot. And in questioning these healers deeply I can see they are not awake, they are playing sophisticated games of self-deception and imagination.

item.title: A recontextualization of Desire
item.description:
in Meditation, Consciousness, Enlightenment, Spirituality
5 hours ago, BornToBoil said:

@Leo Gura how do you deeply satisfy a desire?

It's tricky to say. I don't know exactly. Some people get stuck chasing the same desire endlessly forever.

I think it probably involves experiencing enough of it that you get sick of it and are ready to move on to higher things. It also requires exploration of higher joys.

I feel like I have almost extinguished my desire for junk food. It used to be so hard to say no, now it is almost effortless. And I had a lot of junk food in the past, but it caused me so much suffering I don't want it any more.

Lower desires tend to bring a lot of suffering which you can use against them. But it requires going through that suffering. Play so much video games that you are disgusted with yourself.

It certainly helps a lot when you discover higher spiritual dimensions to life. You can use spiritual joy to replace the seeking of base cravings and raw pleasure.

Sex is still a desire I have not figured out. It's so powerful and intoxicating. I see few spiritual masters have conquered it even in their 60s.

If you're walking to the shops to buy food, there aint suffering right in the midst of the pure doing the walking to the shops. Theres only suffering when you stop doing what will make you full(shop being closed).

I agree it is out of proportion for sure. But how you want to invest is your choice. You don't have to be a gambling kid on WSB.

Quote

Would you be willing to give away some of your say and control over actualized.org to random followers?

Certainly not. This is not what is being proposed. We are talking about employees. And even then, we are not talking about giving away control but about profit distribution. A CEO would still have most say and control over a company. The janitor at Amazon is not going to make executive business decisions. But he will get a nice salary if the company is successful.

I would also make exceptions for small businesses. If a business has less than 20 or 50 employees, then it will not be regulated as strictly and there will be less or no requirements for significant profit sharing since such businesses have far less social responsibility.

Actualized.org is not buying politicians, etc.

Of course I could be a billionaire in today's system if I wanted to. My point is to change the system so that I could not be a billionaire even if I wanted to.

It's like I'm telling you to stop rape, and you're tell me, "But Leo, you could just go rape some people yourself."

item.title: Who Should Make Most Money in Society?
item.description:
in Society, Environment, Government, Politics
7 minutes ago, tsuki said:

@Leo Gura Can you elaborate on your definition of value? Is it objective, or subjective to you?

Of course everything is subjective. Objectivity does not exist in my worldview.

In this case value is simply whatever mankind finds valuable or desirable. Whatever helps mankind's survival. Value basically = survival. And all survival is relative. But human survival has many common features such as food, water, sex, land, housing, cars, etc.

Middlemen and resellers, for example, add very little value to the world, thus they are often made disposable by nature. Anything in nature that adds little value eventually gets killed off.

For example, kings got killed off because they didn't add sufficient value to society. They mostly leeched value.

item.title: Who Should Make Most Money in Society?
item.description:
in Society, Environment, Government, Politics
22 hours ago, Naviy said:

@Leo Gura 

Leo, you often say that you need to be creative to succeed on market and in life. Can you please elaborate - what do you mean by being creative?

Does it mean to provide value to people, like, being productive and useful?

Does it mean to create something new that did not exist before (find new solution, create new product, new approach, new method, new kind of service)?

Or is it a mindset when you are focused on doing something for your authentic reasons?

What do you mean by "being creative"?

Well, creativity is a deep topic. Creativity has many degrees to it.

For the purposes of this thread my definition of creativity is quite a low bar. Just basically any kind of labor that you do which generates value in and of itself without stealing another's labor.

In this case, getting paid to pick strawberries is creative work while getting paid on your shares of ownership of the strawberry company is not creative work, it is leeching value because the core value of the company comes from the strawberry pickers rather than the stock holders. You can easily tell that because if we kill the strawberry pickers the company will not be profitable, but if we kill the stockholders the company will still be just as profitable.

In general our society should be structured such that people who do the most labor get the most rewards. Today it is the other way around. The most rewards go to people who often do literally zero labor. And daytrading is not labor.

See, this is buy design. It's basically a remnant of slavery. Under slavery, the guys who do the most labor get paid zero while the guys who do zero labor get paid everything. And then those guys who get paid everything have the gall to say that they are actually doing labor by whipping the slaves to work.

That is still effectively our system, just abstracted a bit. And most people are in denial about it. Especially those who profit from it.

Ain't it sweet to make money for doing nothing while others slave away?

item.title: Scientific evidence for psychic powers
item.description:
in Meditation, Consciousness, Enlightenment, Spirituality
4 hours ago, John Doe said:

Still not clear on this. If someone claims that they can levitate, isn't the notion of 'evidence' is very simple? That I (or other third-party auditors) can literally see the person levitate, that's it. If the guy can float in the air, cool, film it, have 100 scientists observe real-time and upload it to YouTube or something, and rake in the million dollars like Carl mentioned. I'm not a materialist btw, I'm just confused as to why this hasn't happened yet.

Oh, that's very easy to answer.

If someone posted a video of actual, genuine levitation on YT, your mind would simply never believe it to be real. You would call it a hoax.

Your mind will not accept that which runs counter to its deepest metaphysics.

You can't get 100 scientists to observe it in real time because no serious scientist would believe it enough to even buy a plane ticket to see it for himself. And even if they did, you would just dismiss those scientists are deluded kooks -- not real scientists, because only a kook would buy a plane ticket to see levitation -- obviously.

So how can you prove something which you know isn't real?

You see? You have shut your eyes and complain that you cannot see and yet you ask us to help you. No one can help you in this case until your realize you are actively shutting your eyes on purpose.

item.title: Reality Can't Be Infinitely Infinite
item.description:
in Meditation, Consciousness, Enlightenment, Spirituality
2 hours ago, NOTintoxicated said:

But can it be explained how reality supposedly includes 'EVERYTHING'? Because everything would include a reality that prevents other realities from manifesting.

The moment of awakening is the explanation. Verbal explanations will not work here.

EVERYTHING is EVERYTHING. There's nothing to explain.

Quote

I don't get how there be these colossal "contradictions" regarding the sequential nature of conscious incarnations. If everything exists, and that the conscious source, or "God", will experience everything, (which seems to contradict @Jirh's idea that the 'infinitely infinite' is just conceptual potential, as opposed to 'actualized infinity' which is the manifested reality) how can there be any experience that follows an incarnation of infinite lifespan. If my current lifespan were infinite, wouldn't that mean that my "impermanence" has been robbed from me? I would be stuck forever in this incarnation.

You are imagining all those incarnations NOW. Ultimately there is nothing but NOW. You are fantasizing about all sorts of future scenarios, but the entire future is imaginary.

Stick to the NOW. As soon as your mind wanders into hypothetical spiritual musings you're lost in endless monkey mind.

Quote

Do I just need to try 5meo? I really want to understand at a deeper level, however I feel like the messages I've been receiving from my psychedelic trips have been pushing me to get my life in order before doing anything too hardcore. It's been 7 months since I've tripped, and it was a paradigm shattering experience, borderline nightmarish.. Should I try 5meo regardless?

That's on you.

But if you want to understand EVERYTHING, it would be a good way to do it, rather than this pointless mental masturbation you're currently doing here.

But if you find tripping nightmarish then maybe you're not ready to know EVERYTHING.

See, you ask to know EVERYTHING, but then you recoil in horror and run away. So God himself cannot please you.

Every model is like a finite 2D cross-sectional slice through an infinite-dimensional watermelon. It captures some aspect of the watermelon, but it's far shy of depicting the watermelon as a whole.

item.title: Reality Can't Be Infinitely Infinite
item.description:
in Meditation, Consciousness, Enlightenment, Spirituality
54 minutes ago, NOTintoxicated said:

Well first of all, I don't understand how something can be infinitely finite

Take a look at how numbers work. Numbers are infinitely finite. Each number is finite yet there are infinitely many of them, and you can sub-divide each finite number an infinite number of times more, and each of those you can also sub-divide infinite more times, ad infinitum.

Infinity is a highly paradoxical thing. Contradiction is not a bug, it's a feature. If thinking about infinity breaks your mind, that's not a mistake, that's the nature of infinity!

Infinity creates a lot of paradox and breaks all finite systems, which is why scientists tend to avoid it and sweep it under the rug. When a physicist encounters an infinity in his calculations/equations he considers it a mistake and looks for a way to hide it. But of course the only mistake is him thinking it was a mistake and trying to hide it.

item.title: Why is it possible to make distinctions?
item.description:
in Meditation, Consciousness, Enlightenment, Spirituality
42 minutes ago, 4201 said:

Why is it possible to make things into things?

Precisely because there is no thing that would stop it.

Stopping a thing requires another thing. But if there are no things, then there are no obstacles either.

Quote

Isn't there some thing that is doing that?

No. Nothing is doing that.

Quote

If there was truly nothing there would be no one to turn nothing into things.

There would also be nothing to stop nothing from creating something.

All things are just imaginations of consciousness. You're still stuck in materialism.

You are not appreciating the relativity of things. Stop assuming that things exist as objective facts. They don't. They only exist if your consciousness holds them.

Even the notion of a "thing" or an object is merely something you dreamed up. If you stop dreaming of objects there will be no objects. Reality is not made out of objects nor is reality as a whole an object itself.

item.title: Why is it possible to make distinctions?
item.description:
in Meditation, Consciousness, Enlightenment, Spirituality
1 hour ago, 4201 said:

Why isn't it just all really nothing? Not "nothing" as in not a thing, but nothing as no things and no counter-things (no nothing). Just pure emptiness.

It is all nothing, it is all emptiness.

You are making the mistake of still distinguishing and being biased. You think nothing is somehow different and distinct from something. Which is a duality.

Quote

Why is there possibility for duality?

Because duality is a part of nonduality.

There is possibility for EVERYTHING because reality is unlimited. So what would stop it?

A more conventional explanation would sound like this: nothing cannot stop something from appearing, since to stop a thing requires something to exist. Hence something must come into existence because nothing prevents it.

But even this explanation is not correct because it still assumes a duality between nothing and something. As if something came out of nothing. NO! Something did not come out of nothing. Something has always been nothing. The only full explanation is that something = nothing.

If you don't get it, it's because you haven't awoken to the fact that everything you see and hear is nothing. And no amount of logicking this will do it.

You cannot substitute for lack of awakening by thinking some more.

Yeah I think you're absolutely right. People are experiencing scarcity, but it's collectively self-created. That's partially what I mean when I say that the scarcity is "artificial".

We believe that scarcity exists. That it exists is a metaphysical assumption, one that is ultimately untenable from the highest perspective.

Scarcity is not artificial.

Not everyone can have a house on the beach. Not everyone can eat lobster. Not everyone can see the best doctor. Not everyone can go to the best school. Not everyone can drive an electric car.

These things are finite and must be competed over.

Who gets what is determined by money. It used to be determined by war.

item.description:
in Society, Environment, Government, Politics
4 hours ago, datamonster said:

Enabling other people, i.e. the companies you invest in, to add genuine creative value to the world. 

That's a cute story. But in reality what you're doing is leeching value from the workers who are being creative. It's not like you're funding some start-up in a garage here. You're funneling money to giant companies who don't need your money other than to pay their executives billions.

Quote

Why would it be better to have your savings rot in your bank account to be gambled with by your bank than using some of them to help others accomplish their mission?

Having money in a bank account does not leech value from creative workers because you don't earn anything significant on it.

The key is this: if you're earning a lot by doing nothing, you're leeching. Where do you think that money is coming from? It's not coming from thin air and you aren't creating it. Someone else is creating it and you're siphoning it off.

3 hours ago, romansoloviov said:

Would you consider venture capital exploitative? Venture capital allows smart people to build huge companies quickly which they would never be able to bootstrap. Many companies end up providing huge value: Google (search, maps, YouTube), Uber, Airbnb, + smaller niche companies that do more innovative stuff.

Yes, it's very exploitative. But also, early venture capital is more creative than what you're doing by trading stocks on Wall Street.

Quote

Without capital startups don't work. VCs have a lot of money, so they give it to founders to put it to good use (expecting to make even more money 10 years later).

Some amount of capital lending will always be necessary and good. The problem is when you start trading it for profit by adding nothing. When you buy stocks of Microsoft or Coca Cola, you're not really seeding them with capital. You're just trading and leeching.

2 hours ago, Parththakkar12 said:

@Leo Gura Wait a second... Don't the companies benefit from the investment you make? Don't their stock-prices rise as a result of that? Isn't that a fair way of everyone making money together and creating a win-win?

No! The worker's labor is being exploited and not properly rewarded. The top 0.01% own the stocks and leech value from the labor of the other 99.9% of the workers.

Quote

You talk about offering value to them. Your capital is the value they get! They get to use that money to run the company, then they get to give you returns.

Who gets? The workers get shafted. The value "they get" is the CEOs and other traders who hardly work for it.

Quote

Educate me please. I am obviously a noob in investing, I only know these things in theory.

It's not about learning investing. You have to look at the entire economic system as a pyramid scheme that funnels exploited value upward to those who do not work.

Our system was deliberately designed so that those who work the least get to take the value of those who work the most. This is otherwise known as theft. You are complicit in this system when you feed money into it and get value out of it. If you don't understand the devilry of this design you are gullible.

item.title: Chomsky: Marxism vs Leninism
item.description:
in Society, Environment, Government, Politics
On 2/5/2021 at 3:20 PM, Husseinisdoingfine said:

It’s just Leo kept using the argument of humans are too selfish for a Socialist system, I think that stems from a misunderstanding of what a Socialist economy is. 
 

Point #1: Humans are too selfish and greedy by their nature

#2: ?????????????

#3: Therefore a Socialist system cannot work

Dude, I was born in Soviet Communist Russia. The corruption there was off the charts. Everyone was supposed to be this socialist working for the good of the collective but in reality most people were so damned selfish they collected bribes under the table while proclaiming themselves to be loyal socialists.

And do not tell me that Soviet Russia was not really socialist. They tried to be as socialist as they could and they failed at it because they were too selfish and underdeveloped to sustain it. The same thing happened in China and North Korea and pretty much every nation that attempted socialism. The attempts fail not because they were bad attempted, or because America interfered, but because mankind as a whole is not developed enough for such a collective-conscious system.

For socialism to be sustainable the majority of the citizens must be so conscious and so selfless that they were willing to genuinely care about the greater good of society. This simply isn't possible right. Most people aren't conscious enough to feed themselves and pay the bills.

Socialism can probably work some day, but not at our current levels of development, consciousness, and selfishness.

If you believe that capitalists are selfish, and you believe that socialism is the cure for that, then you also believe that socialists are less selfish. And this is true. But even today's socialists are not conscious nor developed enough to actually make socialism sustainable.

You yourself are not developed and conscious enough to make socialism work. You are overestimating your selflessness. You would not be willing to surrender toys for your children so that some children in Africa get a free meal. You don't understand what socialism requires of you at the psychological level. You think socialism will cost you nothing, but here's a better way to frame it: Are you willing to surrender a lifetime of Xmas presents for your children so that some children in Africa get a lifetime supply of food? The answer is No. What are you gonna tell your child when she cries about not getting an Xmas gift? Are you gonna look her in the eyes and tell her about Marxist theory. Get the fuck outta here. The truth is you're a selfish fuck who doesn't care about society at large. You only want this socialism for selfish reasons to begin with. As soon as you get the opportunity you get grab the money and run.

And that is why we don't have socialism and won't have socialism in our lifetime.

in Meditation, Consciousness, Enlightenment, Spirituality

@zeroISinfinity Need I bring up Ramaji and Ananda as MAGAs?

It baffles the mind, but it is the case that even enlightened people can be fools.

Enlightenment does not guarantee that you will use your mind properly. In fact, if your path toward enlightenment places a strong emphases on shutting off the mind, then it's very likely you will use your mind improperly post-enlightenment because you didn't bother to clean it up and develop it.

Development of the mind is important -- despite what the Buddhists would have you believe. Merely shutting off the mind is not going to solve mankind's problems and it is not scalable to society at large.

You must learn to shut off your mind, AND you must learn to use your mind well when it's called for. And you must learn when to do which. This is the way.

item.title: Rupert Spira on Sam Harris Podcast
item.description:
in Meditation, Consciousness, Enlightenment, Spirituality
10 minutes ago, Joel3102 said:

Sam’s position is that we don’t know whether idealism or materialism is true

And our point is that Sam is God.

Lol

The mistake Sam is making is that he's actually KNOWING that we cannot know. This is not not-knowing, this is knowing. And false knowing at that. If he truly didn't know he would be open to the idea that he could definitively know that materialism is false. But he believes this to be impossible, which is just a lack of imagination on his part.

Sam confuses his inability to imagine how one could know whether idealism or materialism is true with the actual ability to do so. Just because he can't imagine it, doesn't mean it cannot be done. Classic epistemic mistake.

item.title: The Dogma of Consciousness
item.description:
in Self-Actualization

Anything becomes a dogma if you are dogmatic about it.

The problem is not the thing itself but how your mind holds it. And a dogmatic mind will hold all things dogmatically, be it science or religion or spirituality or even nonduality or love. And even -- drum roll.... -- being nondogmatic.

In a delicious irony, the dogmatic mind will turn being nondogmatic into a dogma!

Dogma gonna dog

item.title: Do you think this girl was right to block me?
item.description:
in Dating, Relationships, Sexuality
1 hour ago, Hardkill said:

However, I still a lot of times don't get how or when get sexual or more sexual with women.

Requires lots of trial and error. Lots of experience needed.

Quote

Make it more innocent and cute how without getting into the friend zone?

You can be cute and romantical without being sexual.

Here are two better things you could have texted her:

"You are more adorable than a baby polar bear sliding down a rainbow." (stolen line from Jeffy, but it shows you my point).

"I want to build you a house out of Legos and fill it with exotic baby animals."

Neither of these lines is sexual, but they both clearly tell the girl that you are interested in her romantically and so there will be no friendzone from this.

Friendzone happens when you don't make your intent clear. Besides, this is only the opening shot of the battle. There will be many more lines following it which will also subtly communicate your romantic intent. For example, you can literally tell her something like, "I'm taking you for a picnic in the romantical land of enchanted unicorns. Watch out for the rattlesnakes hiding in the pink mist." If she responds positively to such a text, you know she's interested in fucking you. Your intent is clear and you never come off creepy. If she doesn't respond positively then you know she's not attracted to you and nothing you text her will change that.

Quote

I thought that sexual attraction can be built up through text, like how women get turned on by reading those erotic books. 

That's why I commented. To disabuse you of this time-wasting notion.

You can certainly turn a woman on via texts. I can and have given girls more powerful orgasms via text than past guys ever did with their dicks. But this assumes the girl is attracted to begin with. A very important distinction to learn.

My general rule of thumb is this: avoid explicitly mentioning sex to a girl until you've had sex with her. If you follow this one rule you will save so many blown up sets.

Of course you can be much more edgy and still get the girl. But you needlessly risk blowing it up. Why take that risk? Just to be edgy?

Once you reach the attraction hook-point with a girl, you can get away with some really edgy and sexual stuff. And the hook-point is usually reached within 5 minutes of meeting her face-to-face. But you are not reaching that hook-point via your texts.

If you reach the hook-point, you can politely ask to squeeze a girl's tits, and there's a good chance she will let you. One of the most amazing experiences in game is when you go to the club, hit hook-point within 5 seconds just by looking her in the eyes and smiling, and then politely asking her if you can fondle her tits in front of all her friends, and she giggles and says Yes.

This sort of thing is possible, but it requires really good calibration and understanding of when hook-point has been hit. Hook-point is like the most important thing to getting girls. It's so crucial to be able to recognize. And it's not a function of time because it can happen in 5 seconds with no words exchanged.

When flashy and ballsy game works, it's because the guy reached rapid hook-point with the girl. But foolish newbies think they can do that on a cold girl and it blows up in their face.

When a girl likes you, she will let you get away with murder. But if she has no investment in you at all, you might as well be romancing a brick wall. Don't waste your time romancing brick walls. Look for girls who love you right off the bat. Then sleeping with them will be easy.

The most effective way to get laid is to go to a nightclub, approach every girl and screen immediately for hook-point. Once you find the one that hooks, you immediately screen her for logistics. If the logistics are not optimal, you immediately move on to another girl until you find one that hooks hard and has optimal logistics. Then you pull. Guys who are masters of game have boiled their game down to this. They are very wise to not waste their time.

item.title: How to learn to talk a long time?
item.description:
in Dating, Relationships, Sexuality
10 hours ago, UNZARI said:

@Leo Gura I work a door to door job and I often feel weird when I tak about myself the whole time to the customer but they almost always get really interested. You really think talking like a narcissist would work? Lol I wanna try but it feels dirty 

No doubt it works.

Because it takes a stranger time to warm up to you. By talking casually about yourself you put them at ease amd give them something in the conversation to think about and latch onto.

If they hear something interesting they will want to ask questions, and soon a deep conversation forms.

This is a good skill to practice on the airplane when you fly. Make it a goal to start a convo that lasts the entire flight long. It's doable. I've done it. It's also much more fun than sitting their like a cold zombie.

What's the best way to start a deep convo on a plane? Just start talking about yourself like the persona already knows you.

"So when we land I'm going to get a burger and a coffee. And tomorrow I'm going fishing...."

Bottom line: if you want to be a master of starting conversations you must lead them. You must do the initial heavy lifting.
